title: Can you fully appreciate a song without understanding the lyrics? - Quora

response.answer_text: Depends. I’m really into lyrical interpretation and putting a story or discovering the story to lyrics, but usually, yes. I can make up my own narrative for the words, or apply it to one of my stories (eg: Out of Time by Skogsrå or Waves Break by Sam Padrul and Megan Vice …I have ABSOLUTELY no idea what either of these songs are truly about, but both are relevant to my characters and I love the sound so I can appreciate them without trouble). If I like the sound of a certain song, BUT I can tell/suspect that the words are about something inappropriate or destructive, then I don’t want to put that in my ears, even if I can’t totally understand…that’s an exception.. Of course, there are also songs that I don’t fully understand, and suspect are about something specific (that I might not actually like/support), but I still listen to the song because I enjoy the artist or the sound so much (eg: Skydiving by Lights. I’m like 80% sure this song is about sex but coupled with the video and comic, it’s honestly hard to tell…at the same time I sorta just don’t care cause I love Lights so much :P). For the most part, it’s about the aesthetic and feel of the song and how open-ended the lyrics are. The more vague and artfully worded the song, the more I can just put my own meaning to the words and enjoy it that way. As for songs that I can’t understand because the singer mumbles or the vocals are edited to be almost unidentifiable, it drives me nuts to not know what the exact words are, but I can still enjoy the song if I really like the sound. The same goes for songs in languages I do not understand. Typically, I’ll try to look up the English translation of songs in other languages, just so I know what the story is or at least I can know if there’s any curse words or things in it that I don’t want to sing along with out loud.

The key element to answer that question is: establishing a definition of ‘’fully appreciate’’. When the viewer knows all the aspects about a piece that brings the best chance for understanding the artist’s intent. However, not having all the ‘facts’ produces a artistic effect in the viewer which is just as important. As an artist myself, I value the viewer’s reaction/comment since it shows me things that are totally different. So my answer is: YES, it’s possible. [What you don’t know, you haven’t missed.) But I usually do a search for the correct lyrics for songs I care about or seem mysterious. So, I’d say NO. (The music becomes far more relevant and beautiful when the correct lyrics are understood.) It depends on the artist. Elvis Costello is a prime example of gaining the exact lyrics. His genius triples when you know what he’s saying. Whereas using this tactic on The Ramones gains nothing. Their genius comes from a basic level were the words are not essential. The worst: When the lyrics are understood but the message is pretentious or composed of Hallmark material. [AIR SUPPLY . . .] The best: When the lyrics are understood but the message is still too complex to understand. [DYLAN . . . ] DIG ?

Yes, because sometimes there’s no need of words to appreciate the music or the feelings that the artist is trying to convey. Even their way of singing can be enough to feel and identify what they’re transmitting. In addition, the instrumentalization and arrangements can be so well done and virtuously crafted that you can value the songs for their music and melody. Language should not be a barrier anyway.
